data.title: The 50 Best NBA Portland Trail Blazers Power Forwards
data.meta_description: Over 200 sports fans have voted on the 50 Best NBA Portland Trail Blazers Power Forwards. Current Top 3: LaMarcus Aldridge, Buck Williams, Maurice Lucas ...
data.text:
Ranked By

1.4K votes

225 voters

1 reranks

Voting Rules

Vote up the players who had the most success for the Portland Trail Blazers

Big fan of Portland basketball? Then check out this list of Portland Trail Blazers power forwards. It includes almost every power forward from throughout Portland Trail Blazers history, including current power forwards and past ones. Featuring some of the greatest NBA power forwards of all time, the best Trail Blazers PFs include LaMarcus Aldridge, Rasheed Wallace, Sidney Wicks, Brian Grant, and Maurice Lucas.

In the 2021-22 NBA season, the current Portland Trail Blazers starting PFs and backup PFs are Robert Covington, Larry Nance Jr., and Greg Brown III.

Who are the best power forwards in Portland Trail Blazers history? Vote below and help decide the greatest Portland big man of all time!

Most divisive: Shawn Kemp

Over 200 Ranker voters have come together to rank this list of The 50 Best NBA Portland Trail Blazers Power Forwards

Birthplace : Dallas, Texas

Nationality : American

Team : Brooklyn Nets

Position : Power forward

Portland Trail Blazers: 2006–2015

As the second overall pick in the 2006 NBA Draft, LaMarcus Aldridge immediately established himself as a premier power forward for the Portland Trail Blazers. Noted for his smooth mid-range game and impressive footwork, Aldridge garnered five All-Star selections and made two All-NBA teams during his tenure with Portland. His ability to consistently stretch the floor and score in various ways established him as one of the league's elite big men during his time in the Pacific Northwest.

Birthplace : Rocky Mount, North Carolina

Nationality : United States of America

Position : Power forward

Portland Trail Blazers: 1989–1996

Acquired from the New Jersey Nets via trade, Buck Williams embodied the grit and determination that defined the '90s era Trail Blazers teams. Known for his relentless rebounding and defensive tenacity, Williams made three All-Defensive teams and was a crucial component to Portland's deep playoff runs. While his offensive game was often overlooked, his work on the boards and defensive prowess cemented his legacy in the franchise.

Birthplace : Pittsburgh, USA, Pennsylvania

Nationality : United States of America

Position : Power forward

Portland Trail Blazers: 1976–1980, 1987–1988

Dubbed "The Enforcer," Maurice Lucas was a key player in the Trail Blazers' lone championship in 1977, following his acquisition during the ABA dispersal draft. Known for his tenacious and physical style of play, he was an integral component of Portland's celebrated frontline. During his time with the Trail Blazers, Lucas secured four All-Star selections and solidified his position as a beloved figure within the franchise's history.

Birthplace : Buffalo, New York

Nationality : United States of America

Team : Portland Trail Blazers

Position : Power forward, Center

Portland Trail Blazers: 1989–1997

Starting his career as a second-round pick in 1989, Cliff Robinson quickly made a name for himself with the Portland Trail Blazers due to his scoring ability and defensive acumen. He seamlessly transitioned from a spark plug off the bench to a reliable starter, earning Sixth Man of the Year honors in 1993. Robinson's versatility and consistency made him a cornerstone of the Trail Blazers' playoff runs throughout the early '90s.

Birthplace : Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Nationality : United States of America

Team : Portland Trail Blazers, Detroit Pistons, Atlanta Hawks, Washington Wizards, Boston Celtics

Position : Power forward

Portland Trail Blazers: 1996–2004

Known for his fiery temperament and exceptional skill set, Rasheed Wallace was a versatile force for the Portland Trail Blazers after being drafted fourth overall in 1995. His inside-out game, shot-blocking prowess, and lockdown defense made him a standout player in the loaded Western Conference. Wallace would go on to become a two-time All-Star and one of the most memorable figures in Trail Blazers history.

Birthplace : Los Angeles, California

Nationality : United States of America

Position : Power forward, Center

Portland Trail Blazers: 1971–1976

Drafted second overall in 1971, Sidney Wicks made an immediate impact on the Portland Trail Blazers with his versatile skill set and ability to score in a variety of ways. A four-time All-Star during his time in Portland, Wicks displayed remarkable athleticism and court vision, allowing him to excel as a scorer, rebounder, and playmaker. His all-around talents laid the foundation for the franchise's long-standing reputation for developing skilled big men.
